title: 'Stuff happens fast': Braves live out a nightmare as postseason ends with first-inning meltdown
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Steve Gardner breaks down how the Cardinals were able to advance to the NLCS. USA TODAY Sports

ATLANTA — Just a few minutes into the biggest start of his career, scenarios were already running through the mind of Atlanta Braves starter Mike Foltynewicz.

One run? No big deal. Two? It’s not what you’d want, but good teams come back from that all the time. Even three – hey, these guys won 97 games in the regular season for a reason.

With each pitch, Foltynewicz held out hope that he could stop this game – this very, very important game – from unraveling in front of him. And then...

“I don’t know,” he said. “Stuff happens fast.”

There is no genteel way to talk about what happened Wednesday in Game 5 of the National League Division Series. One team showed up ready to play baseball. The other was prepared to vomit all over itself.

The St. Louis Cardinals advanced to the NLCS with a 13-1 win over the Braves, but history will only remember one thing: A 10-run first inning that was as much an implosion by Atlanta as it was a credit to the Cardinals.

And for the Braves, who haven't won a postseason series since 2001 , giving up 10 runs in a deciding game before even getting a turn at bat is something they may never live down.

“Everyone had sky-high confidence going into that game,” first baseman Freddie Freeman said. “Then them scoring 10 runs, that’s hard to swallow. Everything went wrong from the get-go.”

Freddie Freeman looks on during the Game 5 loss. (Photo: Curtis Compton, AP)

It’s hard to identify the exact point when a bad start for the Braves turned into a full-blown meltdown because there were so many candidates. Was it the leadoff walk Foltynewicz issued to Dexter Fowler after having such exceptional command in Game 2? Was it Freeman booting a ground ball from Yadier Molina that would have been the second and maybe third outs of the inning? Was it the bases-loaded walk by reliever Max Fried to Cardinals pitcher Jack Flaherty?

Maybe it doesn’t matter. It was happening and happening fast, and suddenly a long season and a taut playoff series had been buried under the Braves’ mistakes and the Cardinals’ bats.

“We discussed it at the beginning, the crowd was going to be loud and we had to go out and try to get on them early,” Fowler said. “Last time we faced (Foltynewicz) he was a little hard to see but we knew at the top of the lineup we had to get it going and that's what we did.”

Still, a good inning in a game of this magnitude might be two or three runs. A great inning might be four or five. But 10? That doesn’t happen. In fact, it had never happened to lead off a playoff game.

“You just got to try to make it go your way and believe first off that the tide’s going to turn,” Braves left fielder Adam Duvall said. “I don’t think anyone lost hope. When you get punched in the mouth, you don’t just fold up, you get out there and try to punch back.”

FLAHERTY: Did Cardinals make the right call letting ace go deep?

BRAVES: No foam tomahawks handed out amidst backlash

Of course, all 43,122 people in the stadium knew that wasn’t going to happen. The Cardinals hadn’t even recorded an out yet and players on both sides understood the magnitude of what had just happened.

“That’s going to surprise anybody,” Flaherty said. “Our guys are going to go out and do their job but 10 runs is something else. That’s something else.”

And for the Braves, that something else is the ultimate indignity of failing to show up at all when everyone was watching. This is a team that made the playoffs a year ago as something of a surprise, and when they lost to the Dodgers in four games the mood was upbeat. This time, it was disconsolate, with lots of quiet hugs and players racing past each other to stand in front of the media and take part of the blame.

“I didn’t come through. I know everybody’s going to say what they want to say, but this one’s on me,” said Freeman, who had two hits in Game 1 and two that meant very little in Game 5 and nothing in between. “We all know we had a good enough team to win this whole thing. Last year was a hooray, we proved a lot of people wrong. This year we expected to win the division and go far in the playoffs and we didn’t do it.”

The Braves have plenty of flaws in this series to point to. They could have ended it in four but didn’t. They could have won Game 1 but blew a lead in the eighth inning and didn't convert enough scoring opportunities. Veteran Nick Markakis was 3-for-21 in the series. Catcher Brian McCann, who announced his retirement after the game, went 3-for-16. Josh Donaldson was 3-for-19.

And still, what will likely stick to this franchise the longest unless it wins a World Series is the first inning from hell it put together in Game 5.

“Not even getting out of the first inning, not getting a chance to see the lineup a few times through, it’s very embarrassing,” Foltynewicz said. “Especially at a stage like this for people to see that, to let millions of people down. It’s a tough situation. You don't expect it to go down the way it did.”

Nobody could have. But somehow, with so much on the line, the Braves made their worst nightmare a reality.
description: By the time the Braves came to bat in the bottom of the first, they were already facing a 10-0 deficit.
